transliteration.couplet:
Thayā paramhansa sarve sant, ange tyāg vairāgya atyant; <RHYME_1>
Chaud loknā sukh je kahāve, ūlaṭā anna jevā na bhāve.  <RHYME_1>
transliteration.context: The couplet suggests that all saints and sages renounce worldly attachments and desires, finding true happiness in spiritual pursuits. In contrast, ordinary people find fleeting joy only in material possessions and foods.

transliteration.couplet:
Ek kamanḍaḷu kanthā kaupīn, ene arthe na thāy ādhīn; <RHYME_2>
Kare bhikṣhā māgīne madhyāhne, jakta vāt na sāmbhaḷe kāne.  <RHYME_2>
transliteration.context: A beggar's bowl is filled with noon offerings, but the wind doesn't allow him to keep it; his stomach remains empty despite abundance around him.

transliteration.couplet:
Aṣhṭ prakāre triyānā tyāgī, em vichare chhe baḍbhāgī; <RHYME_3>
Dhan dhātu je sonā sahit, tene bhūlye na chintave chitta.  <RHYME_3>
transliteration.context:
A person who has let go of three-fourths of their desires is considered a yogi, and with the remaining desire, they don't worry about anything in life.

Their wealth or material possessions are together like gold, which doesn't trouble their mind.

transliteration.couplet:
Khān pān paṭ vaḷī pekhī, dal rīze nahi tene dekhī; <RHYME_4>
Pūjā chandan puṣhpanī māḷ, tene māne chhe manmā vyāḷ.  <RHYME_4>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes a person who has not seen the true beauty of life despite being exposed to it, like a cowherd who hasn't noticed the full moon. Just as one adores the idol in worship, this person will eventually come to appreciate the beauty of life.

transliteration.couplet:
Je je kāve chhe sansārī sukh, tene jāṇe chhe dalmā dukh; <RHYME_5>
Deh indriya vaḷī man prāṇ, tene shatru samajyā sujāṇ.  <RHYME_5>
transliteration.context: In this world, happiness is found in self-knowledge and understanding, while misery arises from ignorance. The enemy of the self is the five senses, which can be conquered with wisdom.

transliteration.couplet:
Mān moṭāī manmā na bhāve, sūtā beṭhā Hariguṇ gāve; <RHYME_6>
Evī rītye fare jag māī, nirbandh na bandhāy kyāī.  <RHYME_6>
transliteration.context: The couplet says that a person who is hard to control and restless will not settle down even if they find their match, like the horse Gajalakshmi (Hariguṇ) given to graze freely. Similarly, someone stuck in routine cannot be tied down by any bond.

transliteration.couplet:
Kare gnān vāratā apār, jeṇe thāy jīvno uddhār; <RHYME_7>
Karī vāt ne kāī na māge, māne sahu sārī bahu lāge.  <RHYME_7>
transliteration.context: A wise person's knowledge and character are unmatched, as they uplift the living. One who doesn't seek worldly gain still receives abundant love from others.

transliteration.couplet:
Jan joḍe hāth joī tyāgī, bījā bhekhanu paḍiyu bhāgī; <RHYME_8>
Bhekh dāze lāje mukh kahetā, paḍyā khoṭā vinā reṇī rahetā.  <RHYME_8>
transliteration.context: A person who gives up their hard-earned money and property is like a seed that has been sown in the wrong season; it will not grow. Such a person's face becomes pale, but they will remain poor without any wealth.

transliteration.couplet:
Je je rākhī chhe sādhue rīt, bīje na maḷe vichāro chitta; <RHYME_9>
Sarve sār taṇu jeh sār, sopyu santne prāṇ-ādhār.  <RHYME_9>
transliteration.context: In times of peace and tranquility, my heart remains unattached and free. Just as a tree's roots grip the earth firmly, I have grounded myself in inner calm.

transliteration.couplet:
Je je sādhune sopī sampatti, te sarāye Shvetdvīppati; <RHYME_10>
Prabhu pote chhe dīn-dayāḷ, jāṇī nij jan karī sambhāḷ.  <RHYME_10>
transliteration.context: When one's spiritual wealth is sufficient, they will attain the highest realm of Shvetdvīp; God is merciful and has compassion for His own soul.

transliteration.couplet:
Sant shubh guṇe ati ope, kām krodh ne lobh na lope; <RHYME_11>
Sādhu sarve vaḷī harijan, tenu Harie haryu vighan.  <RHYME_11>
transliteration.context: A saint is one who has transcended desire and anger, and instead seeks divine love. All humans are children of God, and He will protect them from all troubles.

transliteration.couplet:
Atol sukh santne āpyu, sarve shatru taṇu mūḷ kāpyu; <RHYME_12>
Sādhu sarave rahejyo ānande, have nahi paḍo koī fande.  <RHYME_12>
transliteration.context: When one finds peace and contentment in solitude, all worldly conflicts disappear; a sage remains blissful, without any attachment or longing.

transliteration.couplet:
Tam jevā nathī koī āj, em Shrīmukhe kahe Mahārāj; <RHYME_13>
Shīd joīe tamāre pravṛutti, tame grahi rahone nivṛutti.  <RHYME_13>
transliteration.context: The couplet suggests that one should not worry about the present moment, as it is governed by fate, and instead focus on maintaining a balance between growth and decay in life.

transliteration.couplet:
Sadāvratmā shīd bandhāvo, tame guṇ Govindnā gāvo; <RHYME_14>
Sadāvrat melashu sankelī, ṭhālā fānsanu khāy chhe felī.  <RHYME_14>
transliteration.context: The couplet says that one should tie themselves to good habits (sadāvrat) and worship God's qualities (Govindnā), rather than being bound by worldly attachments. Good habits bring prosperity, just like a well-crafted kite (sankelī) soars high in the sky.

transliteration.couplet:
Ene arthe je kharachtā anna, teno karashu have jagan; <RHYME_15>
Evī sāmbhaḷī vālānī vāṇī, sarve sante satya karī jāṇī.  <RHYME_15>
transliteration.context: In this couplet, a person's actions are the foundation of their existence and their path to God; it emphasizes the importance of living truthfully with oneself.

transliteration.couplet:
Kahe sant suṇo Mahārāj, sarve jaṇāṇu amane āj; <RHYME_16>
Have jem kaho tem karīe, āpo āgnā te shir dharīe.  <RHYME_16>
transliteration.context:
When peace descends on the ruler, all will live in harmony today.
One should speak what one means to do, and stand firm like fire and water.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāre Nāth kahe suṇo sant, melī Soraṭh faro nachint; <RHYME_17>
Pachhī jyā kahyu tyā sant gayā, Prabhu pote Soraṭhmā rahyā.  <RHYME_17>
transliteration.context: The saint says, "Listen to the Master's words, don't worry about worldly affairs." The master has gone, leaving behind only his words and teachings.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī satasangī laī sāth, faryā gām gām vaḷī Nāth; <RHYME_18>
Pāṇ Khāṇya Loj Māngaroḷe, maḷe harijan het boḷe.  <RHYME_18>
transliteration.context: A devotee takes a companion to meet God, step by step, and with great devotion; In the city of Kanhra, there is an assembly of Harijans and saints.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāthī āviyā Kāṇak gām, bhakta Jeṭhā Sagarne dhām; <RHYME_19>
Pachhī āvyā chhe Kālvāṇīe, vase bhakta Nātho tyā jāṇīe.  <RHYME_19>
transliteration.context:
The devotee has arrived at the sacred temple of Lord Jagannath, where God resides; and now, he knows his own Lord as his true home.

Or, in one sentence: A devotee has reached the sacred abode of Lord Jagannath, knowing their own Lord to be their ultimate refuge.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāthī āvyā Maḍhaḍe Murār, tiyā karī chhe līlā apār; <RHYME_20>
Jeṭho joīne pāmyo ānand, jene maḷel Swāmī Rāmānand.  <RHYME_20>
transliteration.context: The playful Lord Murar is forever engaged in an eternal play; those who join Him experience supreme joy under the guidance of Swami Ramandeo.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context:
The summary is:

Love resides in the proximity of one's beloved, and only with them can one find happiness like the sacred mountain Parvati. Together with one's love, one should travel the path of life under their divine guidance.

transliteration.couplet:
Ākhu Pipalāṇu Meghpar, tiyā āviyā Shyām-sundar; <RHYME_22>
Rahyā din dash pāch tyāī, pāchhā āvyā Pipalāṇā māī.  <RHYME_22>
transliteration.context: The beautiful dark clouds of love (Shyam-sundar) arrived at the Pipala tree, and spent the night. After dawn, the tree's mother asked about the delay.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: Life is short and time is fleeting, yet we cling to our breath as foundation; Like the morning sun, our lives are filled with sorrow and pain.

transliteration.couplet:
Kahe Mūḷjīne Mahārāj, karya je je karavu hoy āj; <RHYME_24>
Em kahīne chāliyā Nāth, sakhā sarve hatā potā sāth.  <RHYME_24>
transliteration.context: The master of the universe is busy doing His work today, and I am just a humble devotee following Him wherever He leads. I have surrendered to His will, leaving my ego behind to walk with Him.

transliteration.couplet:
Āvyā Meghpure Mahārāj, kahe nahi rahīe āhi āj; <RHYME_25>
Evu jāṇī jane tāṇya karī, shyo aparādh amāro Hari.  <RHYME_25>
transliteration.context: The great Saint Meghpure Mahārāj was silent and did not speak; he just knew that his Lord Hari had committed a mistake. He understood that only God's will can be blamed for any wrongdoing.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: In the past, you were wise and thoughtful tonight, but now your enthusiasm is spent too early; Even if you don't know tomorrow's difficulties, you are not prepared to bear them today.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī āvyā chhe gāmmā Nāth, dhāyo māravā asursāth; <RHYME_27>

transliteration.context: The lord of the village is God Himself, who takes care of the good and bad alike. The breath of life is the Lord's property, and He alone decides the fate of all living beings.

transliteration.couplet:
Dage bharyā hathiyār hāth, tene joīne chāliyā Nāth; <RHYME_28>
Pachhī āviyā Mūḷjī pās, jāṇī Prabhujī potāno dās.  <RHYME_28>
transliteration.context: The one who holds a humble heart and is faithful to the Lord will receive guidance and protection; the Lord's presence is felt even in the midst of turmoil.

transliteration.couplet:
Rākhī rahyo to ākhyamā jīv, jovā param hitkārī pīv; <RHYME_29>
Jyāre joyā nayaṇe bharī Nāth, mūkyu tan chetan chālyu sāth.  <RHYME_29>
transliteration.context: One's life is spent in remembrance of the Lord (Akhyamā jīv), and in devotion to Him, one should drink the nectar of love. The Lord Himself takes care of a devotee who has completely surrendered themselves to Him, and makes them fully aware of His presence.

transliteration.couplet:
Karī kṣhamā bolyā nahi Shyām, pachhī āvyā chhe Bhāḍer gām; <RHYME_30>
Tyāthī padhāriyā chhe Dhorājī, āvyā Khānḍādhāre besī vāji.  <RHYME_30>

transliteration.couplet:

Moṭā bhakta jiyā Mūḷubhāī, jene het ghaṇu Hari māī.  <RHYME_31>
transliteration.context: The devotee has tied up the thread of fate, but still hopes to attain salvation; a true devotee's soul is always yearning for God.

transliteration.couplet:

Tiyā kāṭhīne shīkh ja karī, pote padhāryā hālāre Hari.  <RHYME_32>
transliteration.context: The king of the forest, Mahārāj, is pleased with the offerings at the temple after a long wait. The devotee's sincere and pure devotion has pleased Lord Hari, making their prayer acceptable.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context:
In Rajkot one night, a cowherd from Khirsar wandered away; Meanwhile, his devotee lived with abundance and peace of mind in the same town.

The devotee's life was filled with prosperity and happiness.

transliteration.couplet:
Pachhī Monḍe āvyā bhakta māṭye, tyāthī Alaiye ne Shekhpāṭye; <RHYME_34>

transliteration.context: In a nutshell, the couplet describes a devotee who is so pure of heart that even God has taken them as His own, and their love for God is so strong that it fills every corner of their life. This devotion is so profound that it makes one's life a temple of God.

transliteration.couplet:
Tyāthī padhāryā Bhādarā māī, mās ek rahyā pote tyāī; <RHYME_35>
Pachhī boliyā Prāṇ-jīvan, karīe Jetalpure jagan.  <RHYME_35>
transliteration.context: The mother's loving care lasts a lifetime, just like the moon stays in one place until it sets.

transliteration.couplet:
Jaī Govind Swāmīne kahejyo, tame yagnanā kāmmā rahejyo; <RHYME_36>
Bījo kāgaḷ lakhiyo laī, varṇa thoḍe vāt ghaṇī kaī.  <RHYME_36>
transliteration.context:
Praise Govind Swami and perform your duties diligently; 
Conduct your worldly affairs with patience and wisdom, like a bird soaring high.

transliteration.couplet:
Mānchā Surā Somalā Alaiyā, Mūḷu Nājā Mātarā Māmaiyā; <RHYME_37>

transliteration.context:
The couplet describes a peaceful and serene atmosphere, where the sound of Surah (Quran) and Somalaya (a traditional Gujarati song) fill the air, accompanied by the joy and happiness of family gatherings.

The speaker expresses their longing for eternal life, where they can live forever with loved ones, free from worldly troubles.

transliteration.couplet:
Eh sarve tajī gharbār, thājyo paramhansa niradhār; <RHYME_38>
Jem moṭā moṭā ghar melī, bhajyā Hari tajī jag jelī.  <RHYME_38>
transliteration.context: This couplet speaks of a person who has transcended worldly attachments and is now free to focus on spiritual growth, finding solace in devotion to God.

transliteration.couplet:
Māṭe mānajyo āgnā amārī, mūkajyo sahu manmā vichārī; <RHYME_39>

transliteration.context: The soul is consumed by worldly desires and thoughts, like a flame burning bright, but ultimately leads to destruction. One should perform good deeds with devotion, like offering oblations to God, for true spiritual growth.

transliteration.couplet:

Sundar bhojan sārā karīne, hete jamāḍiyā chhe Harine.  <RHYME_40>
transliteration.context: The couplet describes the beauty of a loved one (Divāḷī) and how they are cherished in love, just like the revered goddess Vanmāḷī. It also mentions that beautiful food is prepared with love, making it a sweet offering to God (Harine).

transliteration.couplet:
Jeṇe joyā chhe Shyām sujāṇ, thaī samādhi na rahyā prāṇ; <RHYME_41>
Tene jagāḍī Jagjīvan, pachhī Prabhue karyu bhojan.  <RHYME_41>
transliteration.context: When Shyam is in his senses, he doesn't remain in a state of trance; His life force stays with him till his meal is over.

transliteration.couplet:

transliteration.context: Life's play is filled with joy and laughter, just like the sun shining brightly today. The King of Mirth will surely come and rule my heart, making it a magnificent kingdom.

transliteration.couplet:

Dhanya desh gām ne bhuvan, jiyā ramiyā Prāṇ-jīvan.  <RHYME_43>
transliteration.context: The couplet expresses the joy of seeing one's beloved again after a long separation and finding solace in their love. It also describes the happiness of being reunited with one's homeland, which is considered a source of life itself.

transliteration.couplet:
Dhanya dhanya e nar ne nār, jeṇe nayaṇe nīrakhyā Morār; <RHYME_44>
Nathī vāt jevaḍī e vāt, jāṇe chhe moṭā sant sākṣhāt.  <RHYME_44>
transliteration.context: One who understands the mysteries of life is blessed; one who knows the divine presence within themselves is truly awakened.

transliteration.couplet:

Tene laukik je lekhashe, mahā mūḍh shiromaṇi teh.  <RHYME_45>
transliteration.context:
In one's own character, all are extraordinary and unique; 
In the world of books, all are ordinary and foolishly brilliant.
